subject: Aerospace Engineering
question_text:
The operating conditions of an aircraft engine combustor are as follows.
The rate of total enthalpy of air entering the combustor = 28.94 MJ/s.
The rate of total enthalpy of air leaving the combustor = 115.42 MJ/s.
Mass flow rate of air = 32 kg/s.
Air to fuel mass ratio = 15.6.
Lower heating value of the fuel = 46 MJ/kg.
The efficiency of the combustor is __________ % (round off to two decimal places).
question_text_latex:
The operating conditions of an aircraft engine combustor are as follows.
The rate of total enthalpy of air entering the combustor = $28.94$ MJ/s.
The rate of total enthalpy of air leaving the combustor = $115.42$ MJ/s.
Mass flow rate of air = $32$ kg/s.
Air to fuel mass ratio = $15.6$.
Lower heating value of the fuel = $46$ MJ/kg.
The efficiency of the combustor is __________ % (round off to two decimal places).

tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem. It requires multiple steps to calculate the combustor efficiency, involving enthalpy change, fuel mass flow rate, and lower heating value. Although it's a multi-step problem, the concepts are relatively straightforward.

answer_validation.reasoning:
Combustor efficiency is defined as the ratio of the actual heat absorbed by the working fluid (increase in total enthalpy rate) to the total ideal heat released by the fuel.

Given:
Rate of total enthalpy of air entering ($\dot{H}_{\text{in}}$) = 28.94 MJ/s
Rate of total enthalpy of air leaving ($\dot{H}_{\text{out}}$) = 115.42 MJ/s
Mass flow rate of air ($\dot{m}_a$) = 32 kg/s
Air to fuel mass ratio (AFR) = 15.6
Lower heating value of the fuel (LHV) = 46 MJ/kg

1.  Calculate the actual heat absorbed (increase in enthalpy rate):
    $\Delta\dot{H} = \dot{H}_{\text{out}} - \dot{H}_{\text{in}} = 115.42 \text{ MJ/s} - 28.94 \text{ MJ/s} = 86.48 \text{ MJ/s}$

2.  Calculate the mass flow rate of fuel ($\dot{m}_f$):
    $\dot{m}_f = \frac{\dot{m}_a}{\text{AFR}} = \frac{32 \text{ kg/s}}{15.6} \approx 2.051282 \text{ kg/s}$

3.  Calculate the theoretical heat release from the fuel:
    Theoretical heat release = $\dot{m}_f \times \text{LHV} = 2.051282 \text{ kg/s} \times 46 \text{ MJ/kg} \approx 94.359 \text{ MJ/s}$

4.  Calculate the combustor efficiency ($\eta_{\text{comb}}$):
    $\eta_{\text{comb}} = \frac{\text{Actual heat absorbed}}{\text{Theoretical heat release}} = \frac{86.48 \text{ MJ/s}}{94.359 \text{ MJ/s}} \approx 0.9165$

5.  Convert to percentage and round off to two decimal places:
    $\eta_{\text{comb}} \approx 91.65\%$

This value (91.65%) is the correct answer.

step_by_step: Identify the given parameters: rate of total enthalpy of air entering ($\dot{H}_{in}$), rate of total enthalpy of air leaving ($\dot{H}_{out}$), mass flow rate of air ($\dot{m}_a$), air to fuel mass ratio (AFR), and lower heating value of the fuel ($Q_{HV}$ or LHV).
Compute the actual heat absorbed by the working fluid (or actual enthalpy increase) across the combustor: $\dot{Q}_{actual, absorbed} = \dot{H}_{out} - \dot{H}_{in}$.
Calculate the mass flow rate of fuel ($\dot{m}_f$) using the given mass flow rate of air and the air-to-fuel ratio: $\dot{m}_f = \frac{\dot{m}_a}{\text{AFR}}$.
Calculate the total ideal heat released by the fuel per unit time (theoretical heat release): $\dot{Q}_{fuel, ideal} = \dot{m}_f \times Q_{HV}$ (or LHV).

Determine the combustor efficiency ($\eta_b$) as the ratio of the actual heat absorbed by the fluid to the total ideal heat released by the fuel: $\eta_b = \frac{\dot{Q}_{actual, absorbed}}{\dot{Q}_{fuel, ideal}}$.
Convert the efficiency to a percentage by multiplying by 100 and round off to two decimal places as required.

essential: First Law of Thermodynamics for open systems

Main Concept: enables: Calculation of specific fuel consumption

difficulty_factors: Correct application of the combustor efficiency definition
Distinguishing Air-Fuel Ratio from Fuel-Air Ratio

textbook_references.author: V. Ganesan
textbook_references.text_snippet: Combustor Energy Balance (Mass Flow): ṁ_f η_b ΔH_rp = (ṁ_f + ṁ_a) C_pg (T_03 - T_02)

textbook_references.author: Hill & Peterson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Fuel-air ratio determination from energy balance: f = (C_pg * T_t4 - C_pa * T_t3) / (Q_HV * η_b - C_pg * T_t4)

video_references.topic_covered: Calculations for Thrust and Fuel Consumption
Cycle Analysis – Turbofan, fuel-air ratio determination

key_insights: Combustor efficiency is defined as the ratio of actual heat added to the theoretical heat release from the fuel.
Air-to-fuel ratio is given, so fuel flow rate is air flow rate divided by AFR.

formulas_principles.name: Combustor Efficiency Definition
formulas_principles.conditions: Assuming negligible fuel sensible enthalpy and perfect combustion reference based on LHV.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula for solving the problem

formulas_principles.name: Air-Fuel Ratio
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute fuel mass flow rate

formulas_principles.conditions: $Q_{HV}$ is the lower heating value of the fuel.
formulas_principles.name: Ideal Heat Release from Fuel
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to calculate the denominator of the efficiency formula.

formulas_principles.conditions: $\dot{H}_{out}$ and $\dot{H}_{in}$ are the total enthalpy rates leaving and entering the combustor, respectively.
formulas_principles.name: Actual Heat Absorbed by Fluid
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to calculate the numerator of the efficiency formula.

industry_examples: Combustor design in turbofan engines like CFM56
Performance testing of gas turbine combustors
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Combustor efficiency directly affects fuel consumption, emissions, and operating costs. High efficiency is critical for economic and environmental performance of engines.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using air-to-fuel ratio (AFR) incorrectly by taking fuel-to-air ratio as 15.6 (i.e., using f = 15.6 instead of f = 1/15.6).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between AFR (air/fuel) and fuel-air ratio (fuel/air).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember AFR = \dot{m}_a / \dot{m}_f, so \dot{m}_f = \dot{m}_a / AFR. Always check units: AFR is dimensionless but >1 typically.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer off by factor of ~15.6 (e.g., efficiency ~6% instead of 91.65%).

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrectly applying the efficiency definition, such as forgetting to subtract enthalpies (using H_out or H_in alone in numerator) or putting ideal energy in the numerator and actual energy in the denominator.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Misunderstanding the fundamental concept of efficiency as 'output divided by input' or 'useful energy divided by total energy supplied', or thinking efficiency = output/input without accounting for the energy increase.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall efficiency = (energy gained)/(energy input). Remember that efficiency is always (what you get / what you put in). The gain is H_out - H_in.
common_mistakes.consequence: Efficiency > 100% (physically impossible) or very low, or a value that is the reciprocal of the correct answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Unit inconsistency, such as mixing MJ and kJ or using LHV in MJ/kg with mass flow in kg/s without ensuring enthalpy rate is also in MJ/s.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Carelessness in unit tracking, overlooking units during calculation, especially with large numbers like heating values, or rushing through the problem.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write units with every value and ensure they cancel out correctly. Practice unit conversions and dimensional analysis to ensure all values are in consistent units (e.g., kJ or J) before performing calculations.
common_mistakes.consequence: Order-of-magnitude errors if units are mismatched (e.g., using kW instead of MW), often by a factor of 1000.

common_mistakes.mistake: Neglecting to convert efficiency to percentage (leaving as a decimal value like 0.9165).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Overlooking the problem's request for the answer in percentage format.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Read the question carefully: if 'efficiency is __________ %' is asked, the answer must be multiplied by 100.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer 0.9165 instead of 91.65, leading to loss of marks.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: CHEF: Combustor Heat Efficiency Formula = \u0394H / (m_f * LHV)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When setting up energy balance for combustor.

flashcards.front: Define combustor efficiency in terms of enthalpy and fuel energy.
flashcards.back: The ratio of the actual heat absorbed by the working fluid (air + fuel) to the total ideal heat released by the fuel. Mathematically, it is expressed as $\eta_{\text{comb}} = (\dot{H}_{\text{out}} - \dot{H}_{\text{in}}) / (\dot{m}_f \times \text{LHV})$, where LHV is the lower heating value of the fuel.

flashcards.front: Given air mass flow \dot{m}_a and air-to-fuel ratio (AFR), what is \dot{m}_f?
flashcards.back: \dot{m}_f = \dot{m}_a / AFR. Remember AFR = \dot{m}_a / \dot{m}_f, so fuel flow is air flow divided by AFR.

flashcards.front: What is a common mistake when using AFR?
flashcards.back: Using AFR as fuel-to-air ratio (i.e., taking f = AFR instead of f = 1/AFR). Always check: AFR >1 typically, so fuel flow is smaller than air flow.

flashcards.front: Given: \dot{H}_{\text{in}} = 50 MJ/s, \dot{H}_{\text{out}} = 200 MJ/s, \dot{m}_a = 40 kg/s, AFR = 20, LHV = 45 MJ/kg. Find \eta_comb.
flashcards.back: \Delta\dot{H}=150 MJ/s, \dot{m}_f=40/20=2 kg/s, theoretical=2*45=90 MJ/s, \eta=150/90=1.67 (impossible >1). Check: Possibly data inconsistent or need to consider efficiency <1. Re-evaluate.

real_world_context.industry_example: In CFM56 turbofan engines, combustor efficiency is typically 98-99% at design point. Lower efficiency leads to higher fuel burn and CO emissions.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: A 1% drop in combustor efficiency can increase fuel consumption by ~1%, significantly impacting airline operating costs and emissions over fleet lifetime.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: This is a direct application of definitions and formulas. Quickly identify the given operating conditions and parameters. It's a direct plug-and-chug: compute ΔH, then m_f from AFR, then η. If you know the definition of combustor efficiency and how to correctly use AFR, it's a quick and high-scoring question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: Modern combustor efficiencies are typically 90-98%, so the answer is likely between 90-98%. If your calculation yields a value outside this range (or outside 0-100%), recheck your steps and calculations.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate approximately 3 minutes for this question. It's straightforward but requires careful arithmetic. Read carefully to avoid AFR/FAR confusion and unit errors, and perform calculations systematically.

alternative_methods.name: Full Energy Balance Including Fuel Sensible Enthalpy
alternative_methods.description: If the sensible enthalpy of the fuel (at inlet temperature) is significant, the energy balance becomes: \dot{H}_{\text{in,air}} + \dot{m}_f h_f + \eta_{\text{comb}} \dot{m}_f \text{LHV} = \dot{H}_{\text{out,mixture}}. This accounts for the fuel's thermal contribution before combustion.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: More accurate but requires additional data (fuel temperature, specific heat). Usually negligible for liquid fuels at ambient temperature.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When fuel inlet temperature is very high (e.g., in some regenerative cycles) or problem explicitly gives fuel enthalpy.

connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: The First Law of Thermodynamics for open systems (steady-flow energy equation) forms the basis of the combustor energy balance, involving concepts like enthalpy, specific heat, and heating value.
connections_to_other_subjects.Chemistry: Lower heating value stems from the thermochemistry of fuel combustion, reflecting energy release excluding latent heat of vaporization of water produced.
connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Mechanics: Mass flow rate calculations are a core concept, especially when dealing with compressible flows in engine components.

deeper_dive_topics: Stoichiometric vs. lean/rich combustion and its effect on efficiency and emissions.
Factors affecting combustor efficiency (e.g., fuel-air mixing quality, residence time, operating pressure and temperature).
